questions.text: A 12-year-old child presented with fatigue, growth retardation, obstructive uropathy, and neurologic abnormalities. A peripheral blood smear revealed megaloblastic anemia. The condition did not improve with the administration of vitamin B12 and folate but responded to treatment with uridine. Which of the following is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is orotic aciduria and the enzyme responsible for the condition is uridine-5'-monophosphate synthase deficiency.

Orotic aciduria is a rare inborn error of metabolism in children. A defect in the enzyme uridine-5′-monophosphate (UMP) synthase in the pyrimidine synthesis pathway results in the failure of conversion of orotic acid to uridine. As a result, there is increased excretion of orotic acid in urine.

The condition is characterized by hypochromic megaloblastic anemia that is unresponsive to vitamin B12 and folic acid, growth retardation, and neurologic abnormalities.

Treatment includes, the administration of uridine (100–200 mg/kg per day), which corrects anemia, reduces orotic acid excretion, and improves the other sequelae of the disorder.

Other options:

Option A: Dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase is responsible for the degradation of uracil and thymine. Deficiency of the enzyme causes excessive urinary excretion of uracil and thymine. Clinical features are nonspecific cerebral dysfunction with convulsive disorders, motor retardation, and mental retardation. There is no specific treatment available.

Option B: Pyrimidine 5′- nucleotidase catalyzes the removal of the phosphate group from pyrimidine ribonucleoside monophosphates (cytidine-5′-monophosphate or UMP). Deficiency of this enzyme causes hemolytic anemia with prominent basophilic stippling of erythrocytes. The accumulation of pyrimidines or cytidine diphosphate choline induces hemolysis. Acquired pyrimidine 5′-nucleotidase deficiency is seen in lead poisoning and in thalassemia.

Option C: Deficiency of xanthine oxidase causes hereditary xanthinuria. This results in all purine in the urine occurring in the form of hypoxanthine and xanthine. Patients may have kidney stones composed of xanthine.

questions.text: The deamination of ______ and the methylation of ______ both lead to the formation of thymine.
questions.solution:
The deamination of 5-Methylcytosine and methylation of uracil leads to the formation of thymine.

Thymine and uracil are pyrimidine bases found only in DNA and RNA, respectively. The only difference in the structures of these two bases is the presence of a methyl group in thymine. Thus, the methylation of uracil will form thymine.

Deamination is the removal of an amino group (NH2) from a chemical compound. Deamination of cytosine forms uracil. Thus, the deamination of methylated cytosine (5-methylcytosine) forms methylated uracil, which is thymine.

questions.text: A child born with a rare genetic disorder presented with failure to thrive and susceptibility to recurrent pyogenic, viral, and fungal infections. His blood reports showed lymphopenia and a diagnosis of SCID was suspected. He was advised to stay in a protective 'bubble' as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the disease in question?

choices.text: The X-linked form is due to the deficiency of  adenosine deaminase
Defective humoral and cell-mediated immune responses

questions.solution:
X-linked SCID is the most common form where there is a mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors. The given clinical scenario and the image of a child in a protective bubble (Bubble boy disease) are suggestive of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). 

 Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) is characterized by:

  • Defects in both humoral and cell-mediated immune responses.
  • Persons with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including Candida albicans, Pneumocystis jirovecii, Pseudomonas species, cytomegalovirus, varicella, and a host of other bacteria.
  • Genes involved are JAK3, RAG1, and IL-7R.

Types of SCID:

X-linked SCID

  • The most common form, accounting for 50% to 60% of cases, is X-linked, and hence, SCID is more common in boys than in girls.
  • The genetic defect in the X-linked form is a mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors.
  • The thymus contains lobules of undifferentiated epithelial cells resembling fetal thymus.

Autosomal recessive

  • The most common cause of autosomal-recessive SCID is a deficiency of adenosine deaminase (ADA) enzyme.
  • In SCID caused by ADA deficiency, remnants of Hassall’s corpuscles can be found.

It can be associated with a defective non-homologous end-joining (NHEJ). NHEJ is a predominant pathway for DNA double-stranded break repair. NHEJ deficiency confers (severe) combined immunodeficiency due to a failure to carry out V(D)J recombination efficiently. NHEJ also functions in class switch recombination, another step enhancing T and B cell diversity.

Note:

The deficiency of adenosine deaminase enzyme was the first pathophysiologic condition to be treated by gene therapy. In1990, Dr. William French Anderson introduced a new copy of this gene, which was carried on a retroviral vector, into a 4-year-old girl suffering from severe combined immunodeficiency (bubble boy disease).

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with developmental delay, short stature, a tendency to sunburn easily, and dry, scaly skin.  He has short and brittle hair and sparse eyebrows. Under polarized light microscopy of the hair strand, a pattern of alternating light and dark ‘tiger‐tail’ bands is seen.  What can be the  DNA repair defect in this case?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of trichothiodystrophy (TTD) which is caused by defective DNA Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER). Features like developmental delay, short stature, photosensitivity, and ichthyosis with short, brittle, and sparse hair are suggestive of the diagnosis. 

Trichothiodystrophy is an autosomal recessive disorder of DNA repair. Most patients carry mutations in the ERCC2 (XPD) gene of the nucleotide excision repair mechanism.

It is a multisystem disorder characterized by short, brittle, sulfur-deficient hair with a pattern of alternating light and dark ‘tiger‐tail’ bands under polarized light microscopy. Other features include photosensitivity, ichthyosis, developmental delay, and short stature.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false regarding epigenetic modification:

choices.text: It causes the alteration of gene expression without mutation
The acetylation of histone favors active transcription
Genomic imprinting is a phenomenon involved in epigenetic gene inactivation
DNA methylation is restricted between cytosine and guanine residues connected by hydrogen bonds

questions.solution:
DNA methylation usually occurs between cytosine and guanine residues connected by phosphodiester bond (CpG) island on the same strand.

Epigenetics is defined as heritable chemical changes in gene expression that are not caused by the alteration in the gene sequence. It alters gene expression without the mutation. Epigenetic modification can cause both gene activation and inactivation. If it causes gene inactivation, it is known as Genomic imprinting.  

The epigenetic modification includes:

  • DNA methylation is usually restricted to cytosines of CpG dinucleotides, which are abundant throughout the genome. CpG islands in promoter regions are typically unmethylated, and the lack of methylation facilitates transcription.
  • Acetylation and deacetylation of lysine residues in core histones which activates and deactivates gene expression respectively. Acetylation of histone favors active transcription.
  • Methylation of histones: Histone Methylation Mostly Makes DNA Mute.

questions.text: A genetic scientist was studying the mechanisms occurring after transcriptional events in eukaryotic cells mRNA. One such process is the polyadenylation of mRNA, which protects against the degradation of mRNA by which enzyme?
questions.solution:
Polyadenylation of mRNA protects against degradation by 3’ exonucleases.

5’ capping protects the mRNA against attacks by 5’ exonucleases. Sequences in the 5’ and 3’ ends as well as in the coding region of the mRNA are thought to either protect against or facilitate endonuclease action.

After synthesis, eukaryotic RNA undergoes extensive post-transcriptional modifications including 7-methylguanosine capping, polyadenylation forming poly-A tail, and splicing.

  • 5' Capping: This is the first of the processing reactions for pre-mRNA. The cap is a 7-methylguanosine attached backward to the 5'-terminal end of the mRNA, forming an unusual 5'→5' triphosphate linkage.
  • Poly-A tail is added after transcription by the nuclear enzyme, polyadenylate polymerase, using ATP as the substrate. These tails help stabilize the mRNA, facilitate its exit from the nucleus, and aid in translation.
  • Splicing: The maturation of eukaryotic mRNA usually involves the removal of introns and joining of exons together to form the mature mRNA. The process of removing introns and joining exons is called splicing. snRNA facilitates the removal of introns by forming base pairs with the consensus sequences at each end of the intron.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is used in polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and is heat stable and obtained from bacteria?
questions.solution:
Taq polymerase is used in PCR. It is heat stable and is obtained from the bacteria Thermophilus aquaticus. It lacks a proofreading activity.

DNA synthesis in PCR is catalyzed by a heat-stable DNA polymerase. It is purified from thermophilic bacteria Thermophilus aquaticus, organisms that grow at 70 to 80°C. Thermostable DNA polymerases withstand short incubations at over 90°, temperatures required to completely denature DNA.

The technique of PCR:

Denaturation- sample DNA strands are separated by heating at 95℃ for 15 seconds to 2 minutes.

Annealing- the primers, added in vast excess, are allowed to anneal to the DNA (typically 50–75°C). The primers hybridize with their complementary single-stranded DNA.

Extension- each strand is copied by a Taq polymerase, starting at the primer sites in the presence of all four nucleotides (dNTPs) at 72℃.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false regarding Telomerase?

choices.text: It is present in eukaryotes only
It is a RNA dependent DNA polymerase
It is an example for a ribozyme

questions.solution:
Telomerase is not a ribozyme.

Telomeres are the end of chromosomal DNA. Since prokaryotic DNA is circular, it does not have free ends and no telomeres. It is present only in eukaryotes 

Telomeres have TG- rich repeats and usually do not code for any proteins. With every DNA replication during cell division, telomere shortening occurs. Once telomeres are almost negligible or non-existent in length, the DNA is unable to replicate and the cell dies. Hence there is a limit to the number of times a cell can divide.

Telomerase is an RNA-dependent DNA polymerase( reverse transcriptase) and recognizes the 3' end of the telomere. It helps in the replication of telomeres. In old age, the telomerase activity is lost leading to chromosome instability and cell death.

In stem cells and cancer cells, enzyme telomerase having reverse transcriptase activity (RNA-dependent DNA polymerase) adds telomeres to the chromosome ends, thereby preserving the length. It allows the stem cells and cancer cells to multiply a lot more times than a normal adult cell.

A ribozyme is RNA with catalytic activity. Some examples of ribozymes are:

  • Sn Rna in the spliceosome.
  • Ribonuclease P
  • Peptidyl transferase
  • RNAse H

questions.text: A 4-month-old baby presented with hypertonia, irritability, and tonic spasms with light. These symptoms rapidly progressed resulting in the death of the baby. An autopsy was conducted and the histology of the brain parenchyma is shown below. Which of the following enzyme was deficient in him?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of hypertonia, irritability and tonic spasms with light and the image showing characteristic globoid cells are suggestive of Krabbe disease. The enzyme deficient in Krabbe's disease is beta-galactosidase.

Krabbe's disease or globoid cell leukodystrophy is a neurodegenerative disorder with severe myelin loss and the presence of globoid bodies in white matter.

It is an autosomal recessive leukodystrophy due to the deficiency of galactocerebroside β-galactosidase. β-galactosidase helps in the catabolism of galactocerebroside to ceramide and galactose. As a result, an alternative catabolic pathway shunts galactocerebroside to galactosyl sphingosine. Elevated levels of these compounds are cytotoxic and cause the destruction of oligodendroglia.

The onset of symptoms is between 3 and 6 months of age, dominated by motor signs such as stiffness and weakness. Patients also have irritability and tonic spasms with light or noise stimulation. They often don't survive beyond the age of 2 years. The brain shows loss of myelin and oligodendrocytes with a similar process affecting the peripheral nerves.

The characteristic and diagnostic feature of Krabbe disease is the aggregation of engorged macrophages called globoid cells in the brain parenchyma and around blood vessels.

Other options:

Option B: A deficiency of enzyme alpha-galactosidase results in Fabry's disease. It is characterized by painful acroparaesthesia, hypohidrosis, abdominal cramping, diarrhea, small petechiae around the umbilicus, lenticular opacities, and corneal dystrophy.

Option C: A deficiency of enzyme beta-glucosidase results in Gaucher's disease. It is characterized by joint pain mostly affecting hips and knees, pancytopenia, convulsions, and hepatosplenomegaly. It shows crumbled tissue paper appearance on microscopy.

Option D: A deficiency in enzyme arylsulphatase A results in metachromatic leukodystrophy. It is characterized by progressive regression of milestones, ataxia dysarthria, hypotonia, spasticity hypotonia, hyporeflexia, and optic atrophy.

Further evaluation showed delayed development milestones, hypotonia, hepatosplenomegaly, and a fundoscopy as shown in the image. Lab tests confirmed elevated levels of gangliosides and globosides. What is the most probable diagnosis?

In the given clinical scenario, history of neurological manifestations and hepatosplenomegaly with elevated gangliosides and globosides with cherry red spot on fundoscopy points to the diagnosis of Sandhoff's disease.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presented with complaints of bleeding from the gums while brushing his teeth and purplish rashes on his legs for the past 10 days. On examination, you notice several pinpoint petechiae over both of his shins. His spleen and liver are palpable.  Bone marrow biopsy shows the following finding. Which of the following is useful in treating his condition?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical scenario and the histopathological image provided is Gaucher disease. Gaucher disease is an autosomal recessive disorder that results from the mutation of a gene that encodes glucocerebrosidase. There is an accumulation of glucosylceramide due to the defective activity of acid β- β-glucosidase. Eliglustat tartrate is a specific inhibitor of glucosylceramide synthase which inhibits glycolipid synthesis and has been approved as a first-line therapy for adults. Miglustat is a second-line drug provided orally.

In younger patients, hepatosplenomegaly, mental retardation and blood cytopenias are observed. In contrast, older patients have a greater tendency for chronic bone disease. Patients have non-uniform infiltration of bone marrow with Gaucher cells, which are lipid-laden macrophages. They give a wrinkled tissue paper appearance. Regular intravenous enzyme therapy is the first-line treatment for significantly affected patients. It is highly efficacious and safe in diminishing hepatosplenomegaly and improving hematologic values.

Other options

Option A: Myozyme a.k.a alglucosidase alfa, a recombinant form of alpha-1,4-glucosidase is used in the treatment of Pompe's disease. Clinical features include hypotonia (floppy baby syndrome), motor delay, cardiomegaly, macroglossia, hepatomegaly, failure to thrive, and poor feeding.

Option C: Aldurazyme a.k.a Laronidase in the treatment of Hurler's disease, also known as mucopolysaccharidosis type I. It is characterized by facial dysmorphism, hepatosplenomegaly, corneal clouding, upper airway obstruction, skeletal deformity, and cardiomyopathy. 

Option D: Galsulfase a.k.a Naglazyme is used in the treatment of Maroteaux–Lamy syndrome (mucopolysaccharidosis type VI). It is characterized by macrocephaly, hydrocephalus, macroglossia, short stature, marked corneal clouding, and contractures.

questions.text: An Indian tourist who has come to Jamaica consumes a local unripe fruit. Following its consumption, he develops severe vomiting, confusion, and hypoglycemia. Which of the following metabolic pathways may have been inhibited on consumption of this fruit?
questions.solution:
Beta oxidation of fatty acid is inhibited on the consumption of an unripe ackee fruit, which has the toxins hypoglycin A and B.

Ackee fruit grows on the Blighia sapida tree, a common ingredient in West African and Jamaican cuisine. Unripe ackee fruit contains the heat-stable toxins hypoglycin A and B. Hypoglycin inactivates medium- and short-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase, inhibiting β-oxidation and causing hypoglycemia.

The resulting clinical syndrome, which is characterized by severe vomiting and hypoglycemia, is called Jamaican vomiting sickness.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD in an agitated state with complaints of nausea, and vomiting. The patient provides a history that he was consuming a high-protein diet. On examination, there was ataxia. Investigations reveal elevated plasma concentrations of ammonia and glutamine with increased urinary secretion of orotic acid. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario history of nausea, and vomiting in an agitated patient following consumption of a high protein diet with increased plasma ammonia levels and increased urinary excretion of orotic acid points towards the diagnosis of Type II hyperammonemia.

Type II hyperammonemia results due to a deficiency of Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC). In the urea cycle, the enzyme ornithine transcarbamoylase catalyzes the condensation of carbamoyl phosphate with ornithine to form citrulline. The deficiency of this enzyme leads to the accumulation of carbamoyl phosphate. There is increased excretion of orotic acid in the urine due to the channeling of carbamoyl phosphate into pyrimidine synthesis. Levels of glutamine are elevated in the blood, cerebrospinal fluid, and urine as a result of enhanced glutamine synthesis in response to elevated levels of tissue ammonia.

Clinical symptoms include vomiting, irritability, lethargy, and severe mental retardation. Infants appear normal at birth, but within days progressive lethargy sets in. Mild forms show episodes of hyperammonemia, manifested by vomiting and neurologic abnormalities (e.g., ataxia, mental confusion, agitation, combativeness, frank psychosis), which are separated by periods of wellness. These episodes usually occur after ingestion of a high-protein diet or as a result of a catabolic state such as infection. Hyperammonemic coma, cerebral edema, and death may occur during one of these attacks.

The laboratory findings during the acute attack are hyperammonemia accompanied by marked elevations of plasma concentrations of glutamine and alanine with low levels of citrulline and arginine. The blood level of urea is usually low. There is a marked increase in the urinary excretion of orotic acid. 

The diagnosis is confirmed by gene analysis.

Management includes treatment of acute hyperammonemia attacks. For enteral use, citrulline is used in place of arginine in patients with OTC deficiency. Liver transplantation is a successful treatment for patients with severe OTC deficiency. Long terms treatment consists of a protein-restricted diet.

Other options

Option A: Citrullinemia Type I also called classic citrullinemia occurs due to argininosuccinate synthetase deficiency. In citrullinemia type I the clinical features seen are due to hyperammonemia and the laboratory findings are similar to those found in patients with OTC deficiency(Type II hyperammonemia), except that the plasma citrulline concentration is markedly elevated.

Option B: Citrullinemia Type II occurs due to a defect in the citrin transporter which is required for the transport of aspartate from mitochondria to cytoplasm. Aspartate is required for the conversion of citrulline to argininosuccinic acid. Deficiency of aspartate results in the accumulation of citrulline.

Option D: Type 1 hyperammonemia occurs due to a deficiency of carbamoyl phosphate synthase 1 enzyme. Clinical features are seen due to hyperammonemia and laboratory findings are similar to those found in patients with OTC deficiency but there is no urinary excretion of orotic acid.

questions.text: A 15-year-old patient presents with symptoms of night blindness, loss of peripheral vision, and myopia. Fundoscopic examination showed gyrate atrophy of the choroid and retina. This autosomal recessive condition is caused by the deficiency of which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
A fundoscopic picture showing gyrate atrophy of the retina and choroid is associated with an ornithine-Δ-aminotransferase deficiency.

Gyrate atrophy of the retina and choroid is an autosomal recessive disorder, caused by a deficiency of the enzyme ornithine-Δ-aminotransferase. Ornithine-Δ-aminotransferase (OAT) is a pyridoxal 5′-phosphate (PLP) dependent enzyme present in the mitochondrial matrix. It has prominent roles in ornithine degradation and in proline synthesis.

Defective ornithine metabolism leads to the accumulation of excessive ornithine in the plasma, urine, cerebrospinal fluid, and aqueous humor. This is responsible for the toxic effects of hyperornithinemia, especially on the retinal pigment epithelial cells.

OAT is expressed in the retinal pigment epithelium at high levels. Damage to the retinal pigment epithelium and choriocapillaris atrophy leads to the characteristic chorioretinal degenerative patches seen in gyrate atrophy.

The disease is characterized by progressive vision loss, nearsightedness (myopia), night blindness, and loss of peripheral vision, and cataracts.

Treatment mainly consists of diet modifications to lower the ornithine levels. The restriction of arginine, a precursor for ornithine in the diet, can lower plasma ornithine levels and slow the progression of chorioretinal degeneration.

Other options:

Option A: Ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency leads to lethargy progressing to coma, protein aversion, intellectual disability, and hyperammonemia.

Option C: Argininosuccinate lyase leads to arginosuccinic acidemia with symptoms similar to ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency.

Option D: Branched chain ketoacid dehydrogenase deficiency leads to Maple syrup urine disease with symptoms of lethargy, vomiting, encephalopathy, seizures, intellectual disability, “maple syrup” odor, protein intolerance

questions.text: A young boy presents with a diminution of vision. He is fair, has elongated limbs, and is tall for his age. A slit-lamp examination revealed bilateral inferonasal dislocation of the lens. Which of the following is not useful in treating this case?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of classic homocystinuria. Methionine is not used in treating homocystinuria.

Classic homocystinuria is a disorder of methionine metabolism. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. It occurs due to a deficiency in the enzyme cystathionine beta-synthase.

Cystathionine beta-synthase is a pyridoxal phosphate-dependent enzyme that combines homocysteine with serine to form cystathionine. The absence of this enzyme results in the accumulation of homocysteine which eventually gets excreted in urine causing homocystinuria.

The images given below show the synthesis of cysteine from homocysteine.

Individuals with homocystinuria present with inferonasal subluxation of the optic lens (vs supratemporal in Marfan syndrome), intellectual disability, psychiatric and behavioral disorders, and skeletal abnormalities resembling those of Marfan syndrome,i.e, tall and thin with elongated limbs and arachnodactyly (slender fingers).

Children usually have fair complexions, blue eyes, and a peculiar malar flush. A spine X-ray typically shows generalized osteoporosis. Homocysteine causes activation of Hageman’s factor (factor 12). This results in increased platelet adhesiveness causing thromboembolic events.

The image below shows arachnodactyly.

The cyanide nitroprusside test can be used to detect the presence of homocysteine in urine.

Treatment includes restriction of methionine intake and supplementation with cysteine, betaine, vitamins B6, B12, and folate.

Vitamin B6 is the co-factor for the enzyme cystathionine-β-synthase. Hence vitamin B6 should be supplemented in high doses.

Betaine lowers homocysteine levels in body fluids by remethylating homocysteine to methionine. Hence, it is used in the treatment of homocystinuria in patients who are unresponsive to vitamin B6 therapy.

Vitamin B12 is the cofactor for the enzyme methionine synthase, which catalyzes the remethylation of homocysteine to methionine. Hence Vitamin B12 can be supplemented.

Related Pearl: Homocystinuria

The concept for treatment:

  • Since homocysteine is produced from methionine, decreased dietary intake of methionine decreases the formation of homocysteine.
  • As the end product of this cycle is cysteine, increased dietary intake of cysteine will decrease the conversion of methionine to homocysteine through negative feedback.

questions.text: A biochemist is studying the structure of a triple helical quarter staggered protein found in fibroblasts. He hydrolyzes the protein and separates the constituent amino acids via paper chromatography. Which of the following amino acid is most likely to be found in the highest quantity in these proteins?
questions.solution:
The triple helical quarter staggered protein found in fibroblasts is collagen. The most abundant amino acid in collagen is glycine.

Collagen is the most abundant protein in the animal world. It consists of three alpha chains held together by hydrogen bonds forming a triple helical structure.

A striking characteristic of collagen is the occurrence of glycine residues at every third position, (Gly-X-Y) repeats.

Proline and hydroxyproline confer rigidity on the collagen molecule. Hydroxyproline and hydroxylysine are formed by the post-translational hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues. This hydroxylation is catalyzed by the enzyme prolyl and lysyl hydroxylase, and cofactors are ascorbic acid (vitamin C) and α-ketoglutarate.

questions.text: FIGLU (Formiminoglutamic acid) excretion test is used in the assessment of the deficiency of which of the following vitamins?
questions.solution:

FIGLU is converted to L-glutamate by the enzyme glutamate formimino transferase. This enzyme uses folate (vitamin B9). In Vitamin B9 deficiency, FIGLU accumulates in the body and is excreted in the urine.

The methyl group in N5-methyl THFA is used for the synthesis of active methionine. This takes part in transmethylation reactions required for the synthesis of choline, epinephrine, creatine, etc.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man presented with burning pain in his lower extremities along with staggering gait and sleep disturbances. Which of the following vitamins is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is burning feet syndrome. Vitamin B5-pantothenic acid is responsible for this condition.

Burning foot syndrome presents as burning and lightning pain in the lower extremities, staggering gait due to impaired coordination, and sleep disturbances. It was first seen in prisoners during the second world war. Other features of pantothenic acid deficiency include GI disturbances, paraesthesia, muscle cramps, and ataxia. Burning feet syndrome or nutritional melalgia was first seen in prisoners during the second world war.

Pantothenic acid contains beta-alanine. Beta-alanine is seen in Pantothenic acid (vitamin B5), Coenzyme A, carnosine, anserine, and acyl carrier protein.

Other options:

Option A: Vitamin B6 status can be assessed by assaying erythrocyte transaminase which is activated by pyridoxal phosphate. Deficiency may present with seizures, mental status changes, normocytic anemia, a nonspecific pruritic rash, cheilitis, glossitis, and depression. Excess vitamin B6 causes sensory neuropathy.  It occurs at intakes above 2 g/day

Option B: Deficiency of riboflavin is characterized by cheilosis, desquamation, inflammation of the tongue, seborrheic dermatitis, corneal vascularization, anemia, and personality changes. Riboflavin nutritional status is assessed by measurement of the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro.

Option D: The most important function of vitamin E (Tocopherol) is its chain-breaking antioxidant role. In vitamin E deficiency, there is no prevention of lipid peroxidation caused due to free radicals. As a result of this, the erythrocyte membranes are rendered abnormally fragile leading to hemolytic anemia. It can lead to ataxia, difficulty with upward gaze, hyporeflexia, and profuse muscle weakness.

questions.solution:

The following vitamins serve as cofactors for various enzymes of the tricarboxylic acid(TCA) cycle –

  • Vitamin B5: Pantothenic acid
    • Active form - as a part of coenzyme A

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with steatorrhea, hemolytic anemia, and ataxia. The peripheral blood smear picture is given below. Which vitamin can particularly prevent early death in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette mentioning steatorrhea, hemolytic anemia, and ataxia along with acanthocytes seen in the peripheral blood smear is suggestive of abetalipoproteinemia. Administration of large doses of particularly Vitamin E can prevent early death in this condition.

Abetalipoproteinemia is an autosomal recessive disorder occurring due to loss of function mutation in the gene encoding microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP). MTP transfers lipids to nascent chylomicrons in the intestine and VLDLs in the liver. Therefore, when the MTP gene is mutated, chylomicrons, VLDL, and LDL are not produced.

Vitamin E and retinyl esters are normally transported from enterocytes to the liver by chylomicrons. Vitamin E is also dependent on VLDL for transport out of the liver and into circulation. Because of the inability of these patients to secrete apoB-containing particles, patients with abetalipoproteinemia are markedly deficient in vitamin E. 

Features of abetalipoproteinemia include diarrhea, failure to thrive, neurological features like loss of deep tendon reflexes, dysmetria, ataxia, spastic gait, etc, hypolipidemia, and progressive pigmented retinopathy which may progress to near-blindness.

Treatment of this condition includes the administration of large doses of Vitamin E. They are also mild to moderately deficient in vitamins A and K, those vitamins need to be administrated as well.

Note: It is necessary to initiate Vitamin E therapy as early as possible to prevent the development of neurologic sequelae which may warrant even higher doses of vitamin E.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme defects does not form a part of Garrod's tetrad?
questions.solution:
Tyrosine transaminase deficiency causes Tyrosinemia (type II) which does not form a part of Garrod's tetrad.

  • Alkaptonuria: Due to homogentisate oxidase deficiency (option A)
  • Albinism: Due to tyrosinase deficiency (option D)
  • Cystinuria: A type of aminoaciduria that prevents proper reabsorption of basic, or positively charged, amino acids:

           C: Cystine
           O: Ornithine
            L: Lysine
           A: Arginine

  •  Pentosuria: Due to the deficiency of L-xylulose reductase or xylitol dehydrogenase, which are necessary for xylitol metabolism. (option C)

Garrod's tetrad is named after the British physician Archibald Garrod, who introduced the phrase "inborn error of metabolism" in a lecture in 1908. His insights provided a foundation for the developing field of biochemical genetics.

The clinical vignette is suggestive of abdominal aortic aneurysm and desmosine is a structural cross‐link found in plasma after the degradation of mature elastin. 

Elastin is a crucial protein found in connective tissue predominantly located in ligaments and the walls of blood vessels, especially large arteries like the aorta.  The maturation of elastin involves the formation of desmosine cross-links from four lysine residues, contributing to its stability and low turnover rate. The levels of desmosine in plasma can increase when there is an increase in the degradation of elastin in conditions such as abdominal aortic aneurysms.  

Williams-Beuren syndrome is an associated developmental disorder (deletions of the elastin gene) affecting connective tissue and the central nervous system. Fragmentation or a decrease of elastin is found in conditions such as pulmonary emphysema, cutis laxa, and aging of the skin. Copper deficiency can also affect the formation of crucial cross-linking in elastin.

(ALA synthase- Aminolevulinic acid synthase)
questions.solution:
The biochemical basis of precipitation of porphyria by barbiturates is the derepression of ALA synthase.(ALAS- 1)

  • Porphyrinogenic drugs - like barbiturates, griseofulvin, etc

  • Low-calorie diets for weight loss
  • Fasting
  • Infections
  • Surgery

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presents with the following finding as shown in the image below. On further investigation, she is found to have reduced levels of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase. Which of the following disorders is she most likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
With the given clinical scenario and with reduced levels of enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase, the patient is most likely suffering from Gilbert syndrome. 

Gilbert syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition characterized by decreased activity of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase, which is responsible for the conjugation of bilirubin. This leads to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, that presents as yellowish discolouration of the sclera (icterus/jaundice) as seen in the given image.

Individuals with Gilbert syndrome are usually asymptomatic except for intermittent episodes of jaundice, which usually occurs for the first time during adolescence, due to changes in the concentration of sex hormones. Some patients may have complaints like malaise, fatigue, nausea, anxiety, loss of appetite, and abdominal discomfort. Symptoms are usually precipitated by triggers such as fasting, intercurrent illness, menstruation, and dehydration.

Administration of phenobarbital shows normalisation of the serum bilirubin concentration and hepatic bilirubin clearance.

Gilbert syndrome usually doesn't require any treatment.

Other options:

Option A: Type I Crigler-Najjar syndrome is characterized by a complete deficiency of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase. It usually presents as severe congenital jaundice (serum bilirubin levels over 20 mg/dL) and accompanying brain damage.

Options C and D: Dubin Johnson and Rotor syndrome both have elevated conjugated bilirubin in the blood, and are due to defective secretion of conjugated bilirubin into the bile.

A 7-month-old child was brought by her mother with complaints of diarrhea and mucocutaneous lesions as shown in the image. The symptoms have been present since weaning was started. The mineral deficient in this child is a cofactor of many biological enzymes. Which of the below-listed enzymes use this essential mineral as its co-factor?
  1. Carbonic anhydrase II
  2. Carboxypeptidase A
  3. Alcohol dehydrogenase
  4. Adenosine deaminase
  5. Galactosyl transferase
questions.solution:
A child with eczematous rash typically in the perioral and perineal region and diarrhea is characteristic of acrodermatitis enteropathica which is due to secondary zinc deficiency. Zinc is an important co-factor for enzymes 1, 2, 3, and 4.

Zinc is a component of many metalloenzymes including:

  • Carbonic anhydrase II
  • Carboxypeptidase A
  • Alcohol dehydrogenase
  • Adenosine deaminase
  • Alkaline phosphatase
  • Phospholipase C
  • Superoxide dismutase

Zinc also has antioxidant activity as extracellular superoxide dismutase is zinc-dependent.

 

Selenium is the co-factor for the de-iodinase enzyme. 

It is an autosomal recessive disorder seen in infants due to a defect in intestinal zinc-specific transporter – Human ZIP4 protein which causes an inability to absorb sufficient zinc from the diet. Oral zinc therapy is the preferred management. The genetic locus is on chromosome 8q24.3. It classically presents while weaning from breast milk to formula, which has lower zinc bioavailability than breast milk. The symptoms are perioral and perineal rashes, periungual dermatitis- Beau’s lines on nails, chronic diarrhea, and alopecia. Children commonly present with symmetrical, eczematous plaques that become vesicular, bullous, pustular, or erosive with characteristic crusting at the edges. The perioral eruption usually spares the upper lip, giving it a U‐shaped or horseshoe‐shaped appearance.

Investigations would reveal low serum zinc and paneth cell inclusion is seen in the intestinal mucosal biopsy. 

Treatment – Zinc – 50mg/day for infants, up to 150mg/day for children

Chronic zinc deficiency can cause stunted growth, decreased taste sensation(hypogeusia), impaired immune function and hypogonadism, and hypopigmented hair.

questions.text: An alcoholic patient was brought to the emergency room by his relatives in a state of agitation, impaired judgment, and combativeness. His spot blood glucose level was found to be 45 mg/dL. Which of the following is responsible for this low blood glucose level?

choices.text: Decreased diversion of acetyl CoA to ketogenesis

questions.solution:
This patient has ethanol intoxication, and increased lactate/pyruvate ratio is the reason for his low blood glucose levels.

The oxidation of ethanol to acetate by dehydrogenases is accompanied by the reduction of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) to NADH. This will result in a high concentration of NADH, leading to an increased NADH/NAD+ ratio. 

Due to this, the following metabolic reactions that require NAD+ are inhibited:

  1. Glycolysis
  2. Citric acid cycle (ketogenesis favored)
  3. Pyruvate dehydrogenase
  4. Fatty acid oxidation

Apart from this, there is an increase in two reactions:

  • Pyruvate to lactate 
  • Oxaloacetate to malate

Both of these reactions lead to a decrease in pyruvate and oxaloacetate levels, which are substrates for gluconeogenesis; a reduced level of these substrates leads to a decrease in blood glucose levels, causing symptoms of agitation, impaired judgment, and combativeness.

A decrease in oxaloacetate can impair the ability of the citric acid cycle to metabolize acetyl-CoA and divert fatty acid oxidation toward ketogenesis.

questions.text:
Match the following with their rate-limiting enzymes:
1- Heme synthesis a- HMG CoA reductase
2- Cholesterol synthesis b- Phosphofructokinase
3- Glycolysis c- ALA synthase
4- Niacin synthesis d- HMG CoA synthase
  e- Quinolinate phosphoribosyl transferase
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1-c, 2-a, 3-b, 4-e.

Heme synthesis ALA synthase
Cholesterol synthesis HMG CoA reductase
Glycolysis Phosphofructokinase
Niacin syntheses Quinolinate phosphoribosyl transferase

Heme is synthesized in the normoblasts except matures erythrocytes. Heme synthesis is partly mitochondrial and partly cytoplasmic. It starts with the condensation of succinyl CoA and glycine by ALA synthase in the presence of pyridoxal phosphate to form delta-aminolevulinic acid (ALA). ALA synthase is the rate-limiting enzyme and is located in mitochondria. 

All nucleated cells including the arterial wall can synthesize cholesterol and the liver, adrenal cortex, testis, ovaries, and intestines are the major sites of cholesterol synthesis. It occurs partly in the endoplasmic reticulum and cytoplasm. it starts with the condensation of two molecules of acetyl CoA to form acetoacetyl CoA synthase. 

The reduction of HMG CoA to mevalonate catalyzed by HMG CoA reductase is the rate-limiting step. it is the rate-limiting enzyme and is located in the endoplasmic reticulum. 

Statin group of drugs like lovastatin are competitive inhibitors of HMG CoA reductase and can be used in clinical practice to reduce cholesterol levels in the blood. 

Glycolysis converts glucose to pyruvate (aerobic condition) or lactate (anaerobic condition) with the production of a small quantity of energy. It takes place in all cells of the body. Phosphofructokinase is the rate-limiting enzyme that converts fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1-6-bisphosphate.

The rate-limiting enzyme of synthesis of niacin from tryptophan is quinolinate phosphoribosyltransferase. It converts niacin or nicotinic acid to nicotinate mononucelotide.

questions.text:
With respect to the Lineweaver- Burk plot shown for a given enzyme and inhibitor, which of the following happens on increasing inhibitor concentration?

where, V is the reaction velocity and [S] is the substrate concentration.

choices.text: Decrease in binding affinity of substrate to enzyme
Decrease in the Km value of the enzyme
Decrease in the slope of red line
Decrease in the maximum number of product molecules catalyzed per second

questions.solution:
The red line in the graph represents a reaction with a noncompetitive inhibitor. Increasing inhibitor concentration will lead to a decrease in the maximum number of product molecules catalyzed per second.

In non-competitive inhibition, the inhibitor binds the enzyme other than the active site. It causes a change in the activity of enzymes, as a result of which reaction is not catalyzed. The total number of products hence formed are lesser. It however does not affect the affinity (represented by Km value) of the enzyme to bind the substrate.

This can be plotted on a graph. 1/v0 is plotted versus 1/[S] and a straight line is obtained. This plot can be used to calculate Km and Vmax as well as to determine the mechanism of action of enzyme inhibitors where v0 is the reaction velocity and [S] is the substrate concentration.

In non-competitive inhibition, Vmax decreases (or 1/Vmax increases) but Km is unchanged. Hence the graphs of inhibited and uninhibited reactions have the same x-intercepts (converge at -1/Km) but different y-intercepts.

On increasing the inhibitor concentration, the slope of the red line (1/V vs 1/S) increases, or in other words Vmax decreases.

questions.text: A test for reducing sugars is being performed on several urine samples. The reagent used for this test consists of all of the following, except ________.
questions.solution:
The test being performed is Benedict's test and Benedict's reagent contains all the above contents, except sodium hydroxide.

Benedict’s test is used to detect reducing sugars. It tests positive for all monosaccharides and most disaccharides except sucrose.

Composition of Benedict’s reagent:

  • Copper sulfate- provides the source of cupric (Cu2+) ions
  • Sodium citrate- complexes with cupric (Cu2+) ions to prevent its deterioration to cuprous ions spontaneously
  • Sodium carbonate- provides an alkaline pH

Principle: All monosaccharides and reducing disaccharides contain a free functional aldehyde or ketone group. When heated in the presence of an alkali, they are converted to enediols, which reduce the cupric compounds (Cu2+) present in Benedict's reagent to an insoluble precipitate of red cuprous oxide (Cu2O).

Substances giving a positive reaction on Benedict’s test:

  • All monosaccharides such as glucose, galactose, fructose, pentoses
  • Reducing disaccharides such as lactose and maltose
  • Glucuronic acid, homogentisic acid, and ascorbic acid

The color of the precipitate gives a rough idea of the amount of sugar present in urine:

Color of the precipitate Amount of reducing sugar
Green 0.5%
Yellow 1%
Orange 1.5%
Red 2%

Hence, it is a semi-quantitative test.

questions.text: A sample of RBCs collected from an anemic baby for a study showed abnormally low levels of lactate production using a 14C labeled substrate. A deficiency of which one of the following enzymes would be the most likely cause of this patient's anemia?
questions.solution:
The above scenario with reduced lactate production by red blood cells (RBC) is suggestive of pyruvate kinase deficiency. The deficiency of this enzyme leads to hemolytic anemia.

The mature erythrocyte lacks mitochondria and is, therefore, completely dependent on glycolysis for the production of ATP. Decreased lactate production in the erythrocyte indicates a defect in glycolysis. The anemia observed in glycolytic enzyme deficiencies is a consequence of the reduced rate of glycolysis, leading to decreased ATP production.

The resulting alterations in the red blood cell membrane lead to changes in the shape of the cell and later phagocytosis by the cells of the reticuloendothelial system, particularly macrophages of the spleen. The premature death and lysis of the red blood cell result in hemolytic anemia. Pyruvate kinase deficiency is the second most common cause (after glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency) of enzyme deficiency-related hemolytic anemia.

The clinical presentation in the newborn is hemolytic anemia with neonatal jaundice, requiring frequent phototherapy and exchange transfusion. Adults usually present with signs and symptoms of anemia such as weakness, fatigue, shortness of breath, and dizziness.

The severe form of the disease requires regular packed red cell transfusion with iron chelation and folic acid supplementation.

questions.text: The glucose transporter responsible for insulin-mediated glucose uptake into adipocytes is ______.
questions.solution:
The glucose transporter responsible for insulin-mediated glucose uptake into adipocytes is GLUT-4.

Glucose transporters, also referred to as GLUTs, are transport proteins in the cell membrane responsible for the transfer of glucose into the cells by facilitative diffusion. Facilitative diffusion involves the passage of molecules or ions through the cell membrane by them binding chemically to a carrier/ transport protein that is responsible for their movement across the cell membrane.

GLUT-4 is a transport protein present in adipocytes. When there is a rise in blood glucose level, insulin secreted by the pancreatic beta cells binds to its receptors on the plasma membrane of adipocytes. Upon binding of insulin to its receptor, activation of the receptor's tyrosine-kinase domain occurs. This activation starts a protein activation cascade leading to the translocation of GLUT4 to the plasma membrane.

Once translocation occurs and GLUT4 is inserted into the plasma membrane, facilitated diffusion of glucose down its concentration gradient into the cell occurs.

Additionally, GLUT-4 is also present in skeletal muscle cells and cardiomyocytes.

Other options:

Option B: GLUT-2 is found in the liver, pancreatic β cell, small intestine, and kidney. Its function is the rapid uptake or release of glucose.

Option C: GLUT-5 is present in the small intestine and is involved in the absorption of fructose.

Option D: SGLT-1 is a sodium dependent unidirectional transporter present in the small intestine and kidney that is involved in the active uptake of glucose against a concentration gradient.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presented to the casualty in an unconscious state. His blood sugars were high, the ABG(Arterial blood gas) analysis showed metabolic acidosis, and urine tests were positive for ketone bodies. The ketone bodies were not utilized in the liver because it lacks the enzyme:
questions.solution:
Ketone bodies are not utilized in the liver because it lacks the enzyme thiophorase.

The above clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis characterized by excess production of ketone bodies. The liver cannot utilize the ketone bodies (acetoacetate, β-hydroxybutyrate, and acetone) because it lacks the enzyme thiophorase (also called succinyl CoA acetoacetyl CoA transferase).

Ketone bodies are synthesized in the liver mitochondria (by ketogenesis) and transported in the blood to the peripheral tissues. Here they are utilized by the following steps:

  1. β-hydroxybutyrate (the most predominant ketone body) is oxidized to acetoacetate by β-hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase producing NADH.
  2. Acetoacetate is then activated to acetoacetyl CoA by transferring a CoA molecule from succinyl CoA by succinyl CoA-acetoacetyl CoA transferase (thiophorase).
  3. Acetoacetyl CoA is cleaved into two acetyl CoA molecules by thiolase and oxidized into CO2 by the TCA cycle.

When higher than normal ketone bodies are present in the blood or urine, it is called ketonemia or ketonuria, respectively. The overall condition is called ketosis. The metabolism of free fatty acids to produce ketone bodies is exaggerated in pathologic states such as starvation and diabetes mellitus, thus causing ketosis. The continued buffering and excretion of ketone bodies deplete the alkali reserve, causing ketoacidosis.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with poor weight gain and failure to thrive. Examination reveals hypotonia, sparse hair, and an unusual swimming pool odor of urine. Which of the following enzyme defects is responsible for this condition?

The clinical vignette of poor weight gain and failure to thrive with characteristic swimming pool odor urine is suggestive of Hawkinsinuria. The enzyme defect found responsible for this condition is abnormal 4-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase.

In infants, this disease causes severe metabolic acidosis, ketosis, failure to thrive, mild hepatomegaly, and swimming pool odor. Mental development is usually normal.

questions.text: A person has defeciency of a vitamin that is required for the conversion of homocysteine to methionine. What is the role of cobalt in relation to this vitamin?
questions.solution:
The vitamin required for the conversion of homocysteine to methionine is vitamin B12. Cobalt is an integral part of the Vitamin B12 molecule.

Cobalt is situated at the center of the corrin ring structure of Vitamin B12. Without cobalt, Vitamin B12 would not be able to maintain its structure and, consequently, its biological function.

Other options:

Option A: A coenzyme is a non-protein molecule that assists enzymes in biochemical reactions. While Vitamin B12 acts as a coenzyme in various enzymatic processes, cobalt itself is not a coenzyme; it is a structural part of Vitamin B12.

Option B: Cobalt is not an enzyme; rather, it is a component of the Vitamin B12 molecule that is necessary for the vitamin’s function. Enzymes are proteins that catalyze biochemical reactions, while cobalt is not a protein.

Option C:  A cofactor is a substance that is required for the activity of an enzyme. Although Vitamin B12 functions as a cofactor for the enzyme methionine synthase, cobalt’s role is not as a separate cofactor but as a part of Vitamin B12’s molecular structure.

questions.text: A patient who was taking high doses of vitamin D supplements for his bone health presented to the clinic with complaints of vomiting, increased frequency of urination, and increased thirst. Which of the following complications is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of consuming high doses of vitamin D with complaints of vomiting, increased frequency of urination, and increased thirst is suggestive of hypercalcemia secondary to hypervitaminosis D. Calcinosis is the most likely complication to be seen in this patient. 

Vitamin D toxicity occurs when there is an excessive intake of vitamin D, leading to elevated levels of calcium in the blood. This condition manifests with symptoms including weakness, nausea, vomiting, frequent urination (polyuria), intense thirst, difficulty speaking, hypertension, and weight loss. The hypercalcemia associated with hypervitaminosis D can cause calcification of soft tissues, a condition known as metastatic calcification or calcinosis, particularly affecting vascular and renal tissues. Excessive exposure to sunlight does not cause vitamin D toxicity as the excess D3 is destroyed by sunlight itself.

Dietary sources of vitamin D include Halibut liver oil, cod liver oil, and shark liver oil.

Note: Fish oil is also a rich source of vitamin A

questions.text:
Match the following enzyme deficiencies with their key clinical features:

1. Deficiency of Glucose-6-phosphatase
2. Deficiency of Lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase
3. Deficiency of Muscle glycogen phosphorylase
4. Deficiency of Debranching enzyme

a) Cardiomegaly, generalized muscle weakness, hypotonia, respiratory failure in infants
b) Exercise-induced muscle cramps, myoglobinuria, "second wind" phenomenon
c) Hepatomegaly, severe fasting hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia
d) Hepatomegaly, mild fasting hypoglycemia, accumulation of abnormal glycogen (limit dextrins)
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1-c, 2-a, 3-b, 4-d.

Deficiency of Glucose-6-phosphatase: Von Gierke disease
Normal Function: Converts glucose-6-phosphate to glucose in the liver, which is crucial for maintaining blood glucose levels during fasting.
Impairment: This leads to Von Gierke disease (Type I glycogen storage disease), causing severe fasting hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, and hepatomegaly due to the inability to release glucose from the liver.

Deficiency of Lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase: Pompe disease
Normal Function: Breaks down glycogen into glucose within lysosomes.
Impairment: Causes Pompe disease (Type II glycogen storage disease), leading to the accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes, resulting in cardiomegaly, generalised muscle weakness, hypotonia, and respiratory failure in infants.

Deficiency of Muscle glycogen phosphorylase: McArdle disease
Normal Function: Breaks down glycogen to provide glucose for muscle energy during exercise.
Impairment: This leads to McArdle disease (Type V glycogen storage disease), causing exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, myoglobinuria, and the "second wind" phenomenon, where symptoms improve after a brief rest period.

Deficiency of Debranching enzyme: Cori disease
Normal Function: Helps in glycogen breakdown by removing branches to release glucose.
Impairment: Causes Cori disease (Type III glycogen storage disease), leading to the accumulation of abnormal glycogen with short outer branches (limit dextrins), resulting in hepatomegaly and mild fasting hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents with worsening vision over the past 6 months. His medical history includes hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia. His recent hemoglobin A1c is 9.3%. On slit-lamp examination, bilateral lens opacities are observed. Which of the following pathways is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
A poorly controlled type 2 diabetic (HbA1c 9.3%) who presents with worsening vision and bilateral lens opacities is indicative of cataract. The most likely pathway responsible for his condition is the polyol pathway.

The polyol pathway involves the conversion of glucose to sorbitol by the enzyme aldose reductase. Under normal conditions, only a small amount of glucose is processed through this pathway. However, in chronic hyperglycemia, as seen in poorly controlled diabetes, the activity of aldose reductase is significantly increased. This leads to an excessive accumulation of sorbitol, especially in tissues that have low sorbitol dehydrogenase activity, such as the lens of the eye, retina, kidney, and peripheral nerves.

Sorbitol, being an osmotically active substance, cannot easily diffuse across cell membranes and tends to accumulate within the cells. This accumulation causes osmotic stress, drawing water into the cells, leading to cellular swelling and damage. In the lens of the eye, this osmotic damage disrupts the normal structure and function of lens proteins, leading to the formation of cataracts. This is why diabetic patients with poorly controlled blood sugar levels are at a higher risk of developing cataracts, as well as other complications such as diabetic retinopathy, nephropathy, and neuropathy.

Other Options:

Option A: Galactokinase catalyzes the conversion of galactose to galactose-1-phosphate. Deficiency of this enzyme leads to mild galactosemia, resulting in cataract formation due to the accumulation of galactitol in the lens of the eye. This condition is unrelated to diabetes mellitus and instead is seen in disorders of galactose metabolism such as galactokinase deficiency.

Option B: Aldolase B converts fructose-1-phosphate to dihydroxyacetone phosphate (DHAP) and glyceraldehyde. Overactivity of this enzyme has not been linked to any specific pathological condition. Deficiency of aldolase B results in hereditary fructose intolerance, which is characterized by hypoglycemia and vomiting following the ingestion of fructose-containing foods. This condition does not lead to cataract formation and is unrelated to the metabolic pathways affected in diabetes.

Option D: Gluconeogenesis is the metabolic process by which glucose is synthesized from non-carbohydrate sources, such as lactate, glycerol, and glucogenic amino acids. While this process is crucial for maintaining blood glucose levels during fasting states, it is not directly involved in the formation of cataracts. Cataracts in diabetic patients are primarily due to the osmotic damage caused by the accumulation of sorbitol through the polyol pathway, not gluconeogenesis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with a history of chronic alcohol abuse presents to the emergency department with confusion, ataxia, and lactic acidosis. Blood tests reveal elevated levels of pyruvate and lactate. Given his history and clinical presentation, which of the following enzyme functions is most likely impaired due to a deficiency, and what is the primary cofactor that is deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms of confusion, ataxia, and lactic acidosis strongly suggest Wernicke's encephalopathy, a neurological disorder commonly seen in individuals with chronic alcohol abuse. This condition arises due to thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, which impairs the function of the pyruvate dehydrogenase enzyme.

Thiamine is an essential cofactor for the enzyme pyruvate dehydrogenase, a key component of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex that converts pyruvate to acetyl-CoA. This conversion is critical for linking glycolysis to the citric acid cycle, thereby facilitating energy production in the body.

Without sufficient thiamine, the activity of pyruvate dehydrogenase is severely impaired, leading to an accumulation of pyruvate and lactate in the blood, causing lactic acidosis. This biochemical disturbance contributes to the neurological symptoms observed. Immediate administration of thiamine is crucial in treating Wernicke's encephalopathy. If left untreated, the condition can progress to Korsakoff syndrome, a chronic and debilitating memory disorder. Thus, recognizing the signs and symptoms early and providing thiamine supplementation can lead to rapid improvement and prevent long-term complications.

Other options: 

Option B: Impaired function of α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase due to thiamine deficiency can also contribute to lactic acidosis, as this enzyme is crucial in the citric acid cycle. However, the classic presentation of confusion, ataxia, and lactic acidosis in a chronic alcoholic is more specifically related to the impairment of pyruvate dehydrogenase.

Option C: Alcohol dehydrogenase plays a role in metabolizing ethanol to acetaldehyde, requiring NAD+ as a cofactor. While this enzyme is relevant in the context of chronic alcohol abuse, its impairment does not explain the patient's symptoms of confusion, ataxia, and lactic acidosis.

Option D: Pyruvate kinase is involved in glycolysis, converting phosphoenolpyruvate to pyruvate, and does not directly depend on thiamine. Its impairment would not lead to the same clinical presentation observed in this patient and is not primarily related to thiamine deficiency or chronic alcohol abuse.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with jaundice, dark urine, and pale stools. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of both conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin. A liver biopsy shows signs of hepatocellular damage. Which of the following processes is most likely impaired in this patient?

choices.text: Conjugation of bilirubin with glucuronic acid
Secretion of conjugated bilirubin into bile
Reabsorption of urobilinogen in the intestine

questions.solution:
The patient presents with jaundice, dark urine, and pale stools, which are indicative of a disruption in bilirubin metabolism. Elevated levels of both conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin, along with hepatocellular damage seen in the liver biopsy, suggest an intrahepatic cause of jaundice, due to impairment in secretion of conjugated bilirubin into bile.

This step involves the active transport of conjugated bilirubin (bilirubin diglucuronide) from hepatocytes into the bile canaliculi. Hepatocellular damage impairs this transport mechanism, causing an accumulation of conjugated bilirubin in the blood, resulting in jaundice. The dark urine is due to the presence of conjugated bilirubin, which is water-soluble and excreted by the kidneys. Pale stools occur because less bilirubin reaches the intestines.

The presence of both conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin suggests hepatocellular damage, which supports the diagnosis of hepatic jaundice rather than post-hepatic (obstructive) jaundice. In post-hepatic jaundice, the absence of significant hepatocellular damage on biopsy differentiates it from hepatic jaundice.

Other options:

Option A: In this impairment, there would be an accumulation of unconjugated bilirubin in the blood. However, the presence of elevated conjugated bilirubin indicates that uptake is not the primary issue.

Option B: Impairment in this process would lead to an increase in unconjugated bilirubin, not both forms. Disorders like Gilbert syndrome or Crigler-Najjar syndrome affect this step.

Option D: This process occurs in the terminal ileum and large intestine and involves the reabsorption of urobilinogen formed from bilirubin. It would not explain the elevated levels of conjugated bilirubin or the presence of dark urine and pale stools seen in this patient.

questions.text: A study focuses on the characteristics of glucose transporters in different tissues. Which of the following accurately describes the glucose transporter found in erythrocytes?

choices.text: It is sodium-dependent and primarily transports glucose against its concentration gradient
It requires insulin for glucose uptake and is found in muscle and adipose tissues.
It exhibits specificity for glucose and related sugars and is independent of insulin.
It primarily transports l-hexoses and is highly dependent on the presence of ATP for glucose transport.

questions.solution:
GLUT1, the glucose transporter in erythrocytes, specifically transports glucose and similar sugars and functions independently of insulin.

Erythrocytes rely entirely on glycolysis for ATP production because they lack mitochondria. Therefore, the uptake of glucose is crucial for their energy metabolism. The glucose transporter in erythrocytes is GLUT1, which facilitates glucose transport by facilitated diffusion.

Key properties of GLUT1 in erythrocytes include:

  • Specificity for glucose and related sugars: GLUT1 can transport glucose and other similar hexoses but not l-hexoses.
  • Insulin independence: Unlike GLUT4, which is insulin-dependent and found in muscle and adipose tissue, GLUT1 is always present on the erythrocyte membrane, providing a continuous supply of glucose irrespective of insulin levels.

This efficient transport system is vital for erythrocytes to maintain their function and viability, as they need a continuous supply of glucose for glycolysis and ATP production.

Other options:

Option A: The glucose transporter in erythrocytes is not sodium-dependent; it operates by facilitated diffusion, allowing glucose to move down its concentration gradient without the need for sodium or ATP.

Option B: The glucose transporter in erythrocytes (GLUT1) does not require insulin for glucose uptake. This description is more characteristic of GLUT4.

Option D: GLUT1 does not transport l-hexoses; it specifically transports glucose and related sugars. Also, it does not require ATP for transport, as it operates via facilitated diffusion.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with developmental delay, coarse facial features, hepatosplenomegaly, and cloudy corneas. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the gene encoding α-L-iduronidase. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present in this patient?

choices.text: Accumulation of dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate in urine

questions.solution:
Hurler syndrome (MPS I) involves a deficiency in α-L-iduronidase, leading to the accumulation of dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate. This results in the clinical manifestations of mental retardation, coarse facial features, hepatosplenomegaly, and cloudy corneas.

Other options:

Option B: Hearing loss and aggressive behavior are more characteristic of Sanfilippo syndrome (MPS III).

Option C: Increased levels of iduronate-2-sulfatase activity are not related to Hurler syndrome; they are involved in Hunter syndrome (MPS II).

Option D: Progressive neurodegeneration with spasticity is more characteristic of conditions like Sanfilippo syndrome (MPS III).

questions.text: Everything is true about the characteristics of apoproteins and their functions except

choices.text: ApoB-48 is produced in both the liver and intestine
ApoB- 48 is a major structural protein present in chylomicron
ApoB-48 is formed due to premature stop codon in apoB-100 mRNA

questions.solution:
ApoB-48 is exclusively produced in the intestine.

Features of various apoproteins include: 

  • ApoB-48: It is exclusively produced in the intestine. It is a truncated form of ApoB-100, resulting from a premature stop codon during the translation of ApoB-100 mRNA in the intestine. The ApoB-48 forms a major structural component of chylomicrons. 
  • ApoB-100 is synthesized in the liver. It is a component of low-density lipoproteins (LDL) and very low-density lipoproteins (VLDL). ApoB-100 serves as a ligand for LDL receptors, facilitating the uptake of cholesterol by cells.
  • ApoA-I is produced in both the liver and intestine. It acts as a ligand for HDL receptors and an activator of Lecithin cholesterol acyl transferase (LCAT). It also has anti-atherogenic properties. 
  • Apo A-lI is produced in both the liver and intestine. It is a component of high-density lipoproteins (HDL). It Inhibits LCAT.
  • Apo C-l is produced in the liver. It is a component of Chylomicrons and VLDL. It is an activator of Lecithin cholesterol acyl transferase (LCAT). It also has anti-atherogenic properties. 
  • Apo E is produced in the liver. It is a component of LDL, VLDL and chylomicrons. It is rich in Arginine and acts as a ligand for hepatic uptake.
  • Apo Lp(a) is produced in the liver and is a component of Lipoprotein(a) that is attached to ApoB-100. It impairs fibrinolysis and is highly atherogenic.

questions.text: A 1.5-year-old child is brought to the pediatrician with complaints of inability to gain weight. During the evaluation, the doctor notices that the child has a developmental delay, coarse facial features, and restricted movements in the shoulder and elbow joints. There is mild hepatomegaly. Laboratory studies show that the activities of β-hexosaminidase, iduronate sulfatase, and arylsulfatase A are deficient in cultured fibroblasts, but are 15 times more than normal in serum. questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is I cell disease. 

It is a lysosomal storage disorder in which the enzymes are synthesized in the endoplasmic reticulum, but are not able to enter the lysosome. It occurs as a result of the deficiency of mannose 6-phosphate that helps in the endocytosis. It is also called mucolipidosis II because it has clinical characteristics that include mucopolysaccharidoses and sphingolipidoses.

  • Developmental delay
  • Coarse facial features
  • Joint abnormalities- hip dislocations, restricted joint movements
  • Skeletal abnormalities- short bones, kyphosis, scoliosis, etc.
  • Mild hepatomegaly

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man is being evaluated for recurrent episodes of acute pancreatitis. His fasting triglyceride levels were 1100 mg/dL. He mentions that his mother was diagnosed with a deficiency of lipoprotein lipase and on further investigation, he too was diagnosed with the same condition. Which of the following lipoproteins will be elevated in this patient's plasma?

VLDL- very low density lipoprotein

LDL- low density lipoprotein

HDL- high density lipoprotein
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the presence of lipoprotein lipase deficiency indicate a diagnosis of type I hyperlipoproteinemia, where chylomicron, triglycerides and VLDL levels will be elevated.

Type I hyperlipoproteinemia, also known as familial chylomicronemia syndrome or familial lipoprotein lipase deficiency is due to lipoprotein lipase (LPL) deficiency, abnormal LPL, or apo C-II deficiency causing inactivation of LPL. It is an autosomal recessive condition. 

These patients show slow clearance of chylomicrons and VLDL, low levels of LDL and HDL. 

Clinical features include hepatosplenomegaly, eruptive/ pruritic xanthomas on the back, buttocks, and extensor surfaces, and recurrent episodes of pancreatitis. On funduscopic examination, the retinal blood vessels may appear opalescent, known as lipemia retinalis. The diagnosis should be suspected if the fasting triglyceride levels are greater than 750 mg/dL.

Lipoprotein lipase is required for the hydrolysis of triglycerides into fatty acids and glycerol in circulating chylomicrons, that transport dietary lipids from the intestine to the peripheral tissues. Therefore, patients who are deficient in lipoprotein lipase or apo C-II (type I hyperlipoproteinemia) show increased levels of chylomicrons in the plasma after a fatty meal.

questions.text: A group of scientists are studying gastric cancer.  They extract DNA from the cell and cleave it using a restriction enzyme. They separate the DNA fragments by running them on an electrophoresis gel. The DNA fragments are then denatured and transferred to a nitrocellulose paper and the gene of interest is isolated by exposing it to labeled DNA probe. Which of the following laboratory techniques does this describe?
questions.solution:
The above scenario describes the Southern blot. This technique is used to detect mutations in DNA.

Procedure:

DNA is extracted from the cells and is cleaved into many fragments using a restriction enzyme. The resulting fragments are separated based on the size using electrophoresis. The DNA fragments are then denatured and transferred to a nitrocellulose membrane for analysis. The DNA fragment of interest is then identified using the specific DNA probe (DNA, RNA, or oligonucleotides).

Variants of Southern blot are:

  • Northern blot- It is similar to Southern blot except that the sample is a mixture of mRNA molecules that are separated by electrophoresis. It is then transferred to a nitrocellulose membrane and hybridized with a radiolabeled probe.
  • Western blot (also called immunoblots)- It is also similar to southern blots, except that the proteins are taken as samples and the probe is labeled antibody.

A polymerase chain reaction is a technique to amplify a selected DNA sequence. It uses DNA polymerases to amplify the targeted portions of the DNA.

questions.text: A 15-year-old patient presents with proximal muscle weakness, vomiting, seizures with focal neurological deficits, and altered consciousness. Laboratory tests show lactic acidosis and CSF protein <1g/L. The muscle biopsy is shown below.  What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the biopsy findings point towards the diagnosis of mitochondrial encephalopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke (MELAS).

The microscopy of muscle biopsy with modified Gomori trichrome staining shows ragged red fibers (arrowhead) with a background of blue myofibres. 

MELAS is a mitochondrial inherited condition due to deficiency of complex I (NADH-Q oxidoreductase) or complex IV(cytochrome oxidase). Children usually present with recurrent attacks of a migraine-like headache, anorexia, vomiting, seizures, proximal myopathy, encephalopathy, stroke, altered consciousness, and cardiomyopathy. Children with MELAS are also frequently found to have short stature.

Evaluation includes MRI showing multi-focal infarct-like cortical areas in different stages of ischemic evolution and elevated serum and cerebrospinal fluid lactate levels. CSF protein is increased but is usually ≤1 g/L. Muscle biopsy shows ragged red fibers as described above.

There is no known treatment to stop disease progression. Anti-epileptic medication is used to control seizures. 

Other mitochondrial inherited diseases:

  • Myoclonus epilepsy is associated with ragged red fibers (MERRF)
  • Leigh’s syndrome
  • Leber hereditary optic neuropathy(LHON)
  • Kearns–Sayre syndrome(KSS)
  • Chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia(CPEO)
  • Pearson syndrome

Other options:

Option B- Kearns-Sayre is a rare neuromuscular disorder that may present as a triad of onset before 20 years of age, chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia, and pigmentary retinopathy. In addition to the triad, the patient may have a complete heart block, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) protein >1g/L, or cerebellar ataxia. Serum creatine kinase and lactate are normal or slightly elevated.

Option C- Becker muscular dystrophy is an X-linked recessive disease that causes progressive weakness and wasting of cardiac and skeletal muscles. It is caused due to mutations in the DMD gene coding for dystrophin. Myopathy develops starting from the pelvic and lower limb musculature, progressing to shoulders, upper limb, and the respiratory system. Laboratory investigations show elevated serum creatine kinase. Cardiomyopathy is also seen.

Option D- Duchenne muscular dystrophy is also an X-linked recessive disorder. Children usually present with delayed motor developmental milestones, pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles, cardiomyopathy, and progressive muscle weakness. Laboratory investigations show elevated serum creatine kinase.
